Definition: Classify the given comment whether it conveys anything impolite, offensive, or mockingly abusive by providing "insult" or "non-insult".

Positive Examples.input: Comment: No wonder Hillary got beat by a circus clown.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment is insult because it is scornful and disrespectful.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: I guess when you're clueless you stick your head into every hole.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment is non-insult because it does not disrespect any group.

Negative Examples.input:
Comment: Hillary Clinton was not my girlfriend.

I did not have sexual relations with that woman.
Negative Examples.explanation: This comment might be obscene but not insult.

Negative Examples.input: Comment: She is weak and useless, time to run her off
Negative Examples.explanation: This comment is insult because it is disrespectful.

Comment: I do not agree that Dr. Marrus' comment was "stupid," "hurtful" and "racial." That is an unfair characterization of the words he spoke.

I interpret Dr. Marrus' words as wry humour, most likely at the expense of Hugh Segal, the Master of Massey College. Far from being stupid, the humour illuminates the anachronistic use of the term "Master" at the U of T. As for the comment being intrinsically hurtful, it's clear that it's not. The black student and Hugh Segal CHOSE to be hurt by the humour, but they could've just as readily brushed it off. It clearly wasn't a comment intended to impugn them personally.

Finally, the editor asserts that Dr. Marrus' comment was "racial," as in racist. That's absurd. A racist comment is one that proposes, supports or evinces racist views. That the words spoken may have had a racial theme in no way means that they were racist.

Dr. Marrus is essentially blameless in this affair. Hugh Segal and Massey College are not.

Comment: Note to ignorant Associate Press and the equally ignorant Denver Post Editorial Staff. Micronesia isn't a country. Micronesia is a sub-geographic area in the Western Pacific. The U.S. Territory of Guam is part of Micronesia.  The Federated States of Micronesia are comprised of Yap, Chuuk, Pohnpei, and Kosrae. 

Moreover, it's the Republic of Palau. It's not a group of islands. It's a sovereign nation. Palau gained its independence on October 1, 1994. Some Americans would recognize the ferocious WWII Pacific battle of Peleliu. Peleliu is one of the states of Palau. When you visit Peleliu, you'll see beautiful memorials to the 2k+ U.S. Marines, Navy, and Army service members who were killed. You'll also see beautiful memorials to the 10k+ Japanese who died in the battle. Palau lost 10% of its population to WWII. Yet the Palauans respect the dead from both sides despite the immense tragedy. If they were Americans, they'd already be tearing down the memorials to the dead.

Comment: So long as it takes 8+ hours to fully charge the batteries at 240V and 45 minutes with a supercharger they will never replace gas vehicles.

Each 240V standard charge station takes a 40 amp breaker at 240V. Your standard house electrical panel is a 240V 100amp panel that already has a 30-40 amp breaker in it for the stove and 20 amp breaker for your Laundry dryer.

You got between $4000-$10000 laying around to upgrade your home electrical service? You will need it.

Comment: First off, where's the non-partisan link documenting your claim that Cohen refused to provide documentation?

And second, why are you whining about the lack of an accuser's proof for anything, when your whole retarded premise was it wasn't necessary for them to do so, and was the sole responsibility of the person accused to prove he wasn't guilty?

This goes fully against the long standing legal tenet known as "The Presumption of Innocence", which is defined as "a principle that requires the government to prove the guilt of a criminal defendant AND RELIVES THE DEFENDANT OF ANY BURDEN TO PROVE HIS OR HER INNOCENCE."

This works in conjunction with another requirement mandated in statutes that states the government MUST PROVE THE CHARGES AGAINST THE DEFENDANT "Beyond a Reasonable Doubt", which is a due process requirement that persons suspected of a crime BE PRESUMED INNOCENT.

The two principles are tied together, and can not be separated- like you are ignorantly trying to do now.

Comment: The point is that you have no freedoms. They have become an illusion. At best, you have government-permitted privileges, which means they can be taken away at the whim of the next president. Maybe the next one, like the current one, will only do away with freedoms that I enjoy, so it won't matter to you and you can go on being a PROUD American. Comment: This is a stupid poll for several reasons:

First, the total percentages add up to much more than 100%
Second, Trump's disapproval rating of 55% is nothing to cheer about since that's what Obama had when he left office.
Third, even though the disapproval rating of Congress is 66%, you're comparing apples to oranges with Trump (1 person) vs. Congress (535 persons) as Congress has had a tougher and more complex job to do than Trump has had so far. 
Fourth, Congress isn't tweeting at all hours of the day and night or holding pep rallies for its known supporters across America to bolster its image and its egos.
Fifth, Congress has never been popular with the people.

But, most critically, what the Hell does a nebulous concept such as "Approval" really mean?

It is not the same thing as asking someone to judge the competency or effectiveness of a person or body of persons. It's more akin to a popularity contest than any serious inquiry into the actual work being done in Washington.

Comment: Whether there is standardized testing in public schools or not; whether the students are in charter schools or not with or without standardized testing is truly irrelevant.

To get into college, a student has to take a Standardized Test.  

ACT, SAT, whatever, you have to take and pass a Standardized Test or You Don't Get In!

If you don't graduate from high school or at least pass a Standardized  GED test You Don't Get In!

If you don't learn English to Standard or you don't learn Math to Standard you don't get to go to college until you do.

The same thing is true if you want to be a licensed electrician or many other non-college training courses.

If you can't pass their specific Standardized Test, You Don't Get In!

And, once you get through College, if you want to go on to Graduate School you have to take and pass the GRE (Graduate Records Exam).

Or if you want to go to Law School you have to take and pass the LSAT (Law School Aptitude Test).

Failure to teach issue?

Comment: Part 4.

The Eastern emperor, Theodosius II, and the Western emperor, Valentinian III, called a council at Ephesus in 431. (It is a belief of some traditionalists that the popes called all the councils -- all of the first seven were called by the Roman emperors. Cyril  came, took command of the council, rammed through a condemnation of Nestorius and deposed him within a day. Nestorius was not given a chance to defend himself, and was shot out to a monastery in the Egyptian desert under guard.

Comment: "he was also content to exploit Chinese Labour to build the CPR."

Comment: But that's just it.  We aren't lowering expectations by accommodating students.  We are providing a range of acceptable options for a student with a verifiable learning need to demonstrate that they have mastered the material.  Students must perform at an acceptable academic level.  Despite what some people here want to believe, Wente included, we are not handing out high grades, or degrees.  We are not watering down our expectations.  Rather, we are changing how material is delivered, processed, or how knowledge is demonstrated (i.e: a student is examined orally vs. written).  In the end the student is provided with opportunities to demonstrate that they know the material, rather than being told that because they learn or work differently,  they CAN'T learn the material.  By doing the latter we dismiss a lot of human potential.

Comment: "" According to a comprehensive, rigorous study (released October 2012) by the Department of Health and Human Services, which operates Head Start, 

Looking across the full study period, from the beginning of Head Start through 3rd grade, the evidence is clear that access to Head Start … had few impacts on children in kindergarten through 3rd grade … .

In summary, there were initial positive impacts from having access to Head Start, but by the end of 3rd grade there were very few impacts found for either cohort in any of the four domains of cognitive, social-emotional, health and parenting practices. Comment: So they claim the People will loose the Right of Initiative and Referendum if this Proposition is passed - in fact, it will likely be the end of the world - or close. Comment: Another risk to buying something that has run up 30% in a year is the prospect of negative equity.

If you put 20% down, and the house goes back to where it was only a year ago (30% lower), you are in a negative equity position.  Meaning you will shell out cash to the bank if you sell the house (because the price will be below the amount of the mortgage).

This happened to my parents - they bought in 1988 and a few years later were in the position of having the value of the house fall below the amount of the mortgage.  They couldn't sell it because it meant finding an extra $100k to pay to the bank on top of the selling price of the house.

Keep that in mind when you buy something that runs this quick - it only has to "correct" to where it was a year or two ago and you will be locked into a bad situation.

Comment: That isn't how it works. The T limit is for all women. There are lots of cisgender women out there with physical differences that give them higher than average T. 

If you learned about transgender women, you would find out that they tend to have lower than average T, especially after surgery. In women, T is produced at least partly in the ovaries. Trans women don't have those, so they don't get as high of T levels. And before surgery, they take drugs to block testosterone, and those along with E often reduce T to lower than average levels.

Besides, the idea that all women have average T levels is a complete falsehood. The average exists because women (yes all of them) are all over the map. The limit exists for that reason too. 

Either way, if you want to address the T limit in sports, be prepared to kick a lot of cisgender women out too, because that is what you would be doing.

Comment: In a comment above, I said this writer reminds me of Cliff from Cheers. Since the topic has turned to beer, it seems appropriate to share one of his classic scientific explanations:

"Well ya see, Norm, it’s like this… A herd of buffalo can only move as fast as the slowest buffalo. And when the herd is hunted, it is the slowest and weakest ones at the back that are killed first. This natural selection is good for the herd as a whole, because the general speed and health of the whole group keeps improving by the regular killing of the weakest members. In much the same way, the human brain can only operate as fast as the slowest brain cells. Excessive intake of alcohol, as we know, kills brain cells. But naturally it attacks the slowest and weakest brain cells first. In this way, regular consumption of beer eliminates the weaker brain cells, making the brain a faster and more efficient machine. That’s why you always feel smarter after a few beers.”

Who could argue with such wisdom?

Comment: The Obama era was the after effect of the Bush era, just as the Trump era is the after effect of the Obama era. The Trudeau era is the after effect of the Harper era, which was an after effect of the Chretien/Martin era.

It's not surprising there is a noticeable change of approach after a change of party in power.  However, the increasing "whiplash" nature of these after effect eras, with the flames fueled by the media and social media, promotes a fixation on "narrative management" to placate the mobs, even if nothing substantive changes afterward.  

My concern is that the next "after effect era" for Canada will be an excessive whiplash back to the right, borne of Trudeau's superficial pandering to the left (indeed, out-flanking the NDP to their left!).

We lament the poor Americans with their polarized two-party rule, but Canada doesn't really have a middle-road party either.  So we, too, go through the yo-yo diet of political power too....and the swings are getting more extreme.

1) They're not light, which is why PEs design the necessary structures to hold them, not just anchored to the ground, but also from being swept away under very windy conditions.
2) They might protect most of the underlying building, hail can severely damage them and the continuous exposure to sunlight (UV) reduces their efficiency (they have a fixed lifespan).
3) Accumulated snowfall eliminates all electrical generation.
Did that help?

Comment: This whole disaster, and it will be a disaster, has occurred because the good people of Scarborough are convinced that a subway is somehow a superior type of transit and everything else is a third-rate insult. 
In reality a subway is just a train that runs underground, and putting it underground doesn't somehow make it "better". The best type of transit is the one that makes sense for any given situation, and the Scarborough subway makes no sense because there simply isn't the density to justify it. Not now, and not in some mythical future, because the development it's supposed to attract is simply not going to materialize. This shiny bauble is going to be a massive financial disaster - both on the capital/construction side and on the taxpayer subsidies it will eat up for generations.

Comment: "Last April the Anchorage Parks and Recreation Commission approved an idea conceived by Singletrack Advocates, a local nonprofit, to build 6 to 8 miles of singletrack trails in the park. Construction was to start this summer.
Singletrack trails are skinny mountain bike trails, approximately the width of the bike. Anchorage has more than 76 miles of designated mountain bike trails, according to Singletrack Advocates' website. At least 24 miles have been designed specifically for singletrack users."

Mountain bike trails involve certain things, such as mountains, and singletrack.  Once it's not singletrack, it's some kind of path or double-track ATV/road.  Many mountain bikers seek out the singletrack trails, because this is the mountain biking experience.  This is what you get when you go out on the Kenai Peninsula and other places.  I'm not sure how much you've traveled, but in places down South, they call forest roads, well, forest roads, even if they are not open to vehicles.

Comment: Some notes:

Vancouver's $2.4 billion Canada Line is a heavy-rail metro built as a light-metro, but because the system has 40 metre long station platforms, it can only operate 41 metre long trains. This greatly constricts capacity as the Canada Line has about one half the capacity of the Expo and Millennium Lines which operate ALRT/ART light metro, a proprietary railway made by Bombardier Inc and SNC Lavalin (they own the patents), which stations have 80 metre long station platforms.

For what is said about the Canada line, it has less capacity than a simple modern streetcar line costing a fraction to build.

I would strongly suggest that if the Caisse, Bombardier and SNC are involved with a transit scheme, run, don't walk away from it!

Comment: As a KIUC customer, I was disappointed that my PV installation would not qualify for NEM, but once I understood that there are costs involved in the transport infrastructure and that max PV power is not generated at a time when it is most needed and that watts are not "fungible" (a watt at noon isn't worth as much as a watt at midnight), it didn't take me long to "get over it".

KIUC has been forward thinking for the last 15 years (when I first became a customer).  They are one of the first utilities to take advantage of the Tesla/Solar City challenge to install battery backup.  Of course, KIUC has the advantage of being small enough that if the promised technology doesn't work out, Tesla will still survive.  

The single criticism I can level at KIUC is that they installed cell-based rather than fiber based smart meters preventing them from competing with Oceanic cable for internet options.   

Still, Dave Bissell is my hero, followed by Pat Gegen and the rest of the KIUC board.

Comment: These are my rules to select a stock. Not dissing anyone else but it works for me:

Look at the chart over 50 years and try to find something that approximates a straight line from the bottom left hand corner of your screen to the top right hand corner. Then back it up by looking at the profitability as measured by return in capital as measured in cash terms and valuation by price to free cash flow. Avoid debt laden companies. Avoid story stocks hyped up on BNN like Timminco. Invest in an industry which is immune to things you cannot predict. If you were not clever enough to predict the oil price decline in 2014 why are you in oil stocks in a big way? Buy something with a good dividend you can live on (over 3.5%) and a dividend growth rate above inflation. Check the dividend cover against free cash flow and earnings. Be diversified well to guard against incompetent or crooked management teams but don't diversify away from your investment style or rules. Good luck in 2017 everyone.

Comment: As the article stated, Hydro’s 900-megawatt Burrard Thermal Plant is "the cleanest operating natural gas standby plant in North America," but you are arguing that it's misguided to choose plants like this over the dam. If you ignore the research that dams' reservoirs emit methane gas, this may seem to make sense.

But one thing about generating plants is they can be closed relatively quickly, and indeed, older technology generating plants are being shut down. The closure of the huge Navajo Generating Station in Arizona was recently announced, closing 25 years earlier than planned, and the closure of the Burrard plants proves this too.

But dams? Sorry. but that's a 100 year commitment to operate no matter what new tech comes along. And even if you did want to shut it down and drain the flooded lands, that would also take tons of money, and the drained land would be wrecked for at least a generation. 

The Site C dam would be a permanent, expensive mistake, so let's not build it.

Comment: I believe that for most inmates of Federal Institutions their access to high quality healthcare is better then what they receive in the community. From what I have observed, many, or most inmates lead a healthier lifestyle while incarcerated than on the outside, especially on the street. In almost all cases inmates typically enjoy better diets, and have improved sleeping habits than they maintained before incarcerated. In fact, most inmates look younger after their sentences has expired. These isolated cases in this piece are exaggerated, And it appears to me that the experts at the conference where quoting examples from reports and not face to face interviews or observations. Not to say that living in prison is a holiday, it clearly isn't, but  the reality is that for most offenders in Canada if their have reached the point of being incarcerated they have done little to reduce their risk factors which resulted in their conviction. Much of this article is based on wishful thinking.

Comment: That is pure nonsense, and I don't care what your "studies that prove it" have to say.  Do those studies also take into account the increasing impatience and incompetence of American drivers?  Do those studies also take into account local conditions, such as the fact that our roads in Alaska are slippery with ice and snow for fully half of the year?

Roundabouts are a travesty and a triumph of theory over fact.  They cause massive backups during busy times of the day, as other drivers have noted, as they do not allow in any way for breaks in traffic from the prevailing direction during times of heavy traffic volume.  Moreover, each one is necessarily unique in its construction and traffic flow, unlike a conventional intersection, making them inherently confusing for a fair percentage of drivers, no matter how long they have been in place.  On top of that, roundabouts are wasteful of fuel, as they cause EVERYONE going through them to come to a near-complete or total stop.

Comment: Thanks for the question, Tundramoss. The "good/bad/sorta" rating is going to vary by person, and that's how it should work. If you are asked to rate a comment that makes you mad or you think is stupid, vote "bad" on that, but if it doesn't contain uncivil things, like abuse, namecalling, a physical or bodily threat, or isn't spam, you should still vote civil. Voting "Bad," in other words, doesn't lock you into voting uncivil on the same comment. You can use whether or not you agree with someone to vote "bad," but I think it'd be possible to disagree yet still think a comment is good. Maybe someone expresses an opposing view well, or links to a source you hadn't considered? Those to me would be times to vote "good" even if there's disagreement.

KAILUA, Hawaii — During her  visit to Maui and the home of close family friend Oprah Winfrey, First Lady Michelle Obama was escorted by Maui police.
The tab for that protection? $54,233.70, said a spokesman for the Maui Police Department.
That’s a drop in the bucket, though.
Honolulu police protected the first family while they spent some 15 days during the holidays in Kailua, Oahu.
Michelle Yu, spokeswoman for the Honolulu Police Department, said Thursday the department spent $293,731.99 for overtime only, an expense that excludes normal salary pay.
Neither county police department will seek federal reimbursement for those expenses, putting the burden on local taxpayers.

Comment: cont'd

The essence of Keynes' theory was that the government should "smooth out" the natural business cycle by stimulating the economy in down cycles with government spending paid for by deficits and lower taxes, then when the economy recovers, cut spending and raise taxes to pay back the deficits.  But the latter never happens because, politically, raising taxed gets you de-elected, and most of the stimulus spending has been for entitlements that are difficult to take back.  So, we get spiraling debt.

In 2000, the average interest rate on the National Debt was 6.34% on about $5.7 Trillion, or $361 Billion/yr.  Today, the debt is $20 Trillion, about 3.5 times higher than in 2000.  The average interest rate on that debt over the past year due to artifically low rates has been 2.34%, keeping to cost of servicing that debt at about $460 billion over the past fiscal year, only about 27% more interest on 350% as much debt. Comment: In parts of the article the Klein writes as though he doesn't understand the very concept of insurance. For insurance to work effectively you need to have a larger, rather than smaller, pool of enrollees. Why? because a large pool of insured guarantees that you will have a mix of the old and sick along with the young and healthy. That's the only way insurance can work. Otherwise, only those who have an immediate need will enroll and the cost of paying for their medical bills will bankrupt the insurance company. In a healthy market, these people are indirectly subsidized by the young and healthy who pay premiums but have very low actual medical costs. And, don't forget that even the young and healthy can suffer medical catastrophes. Finally, when Klein writes "if there were functional markets where healthier individuals could purchase cheaper insurance" he seems to misunderstand ObamaCare, which allows insurance companies to charge the older 3 times more than they charge the young.

Comment: I am not an expert, but have read quite a bit about Alzheimer's disease research and treatment and I think it is accurate to say that there is no drug that "slows the progression of the disease".  The drugs prescribed today treat symptoms and have a positive impact on quality of life but researchers still do not know what causes Alzheimer's disease, so there really is no cure.  There are a lot of theories and there is a lot of research happening but there is really no happy ending for those experiencing cognitive decline due to Alzheimers' and related dementias right now.  Early diagnosis is important because sometimes the symptoms are related to a treatable condition.

Comment: How you use your property is not an unfettered right. If it affects others in your community (and it invariably does), then they get to have a say in it. If it was otherwise, I could buy the home next to yours, and turn it into an all-night bar and night-club, complete with loud music. You would, of course, always be free to sell your home if you didn't like it. Good luck with that.

If your land was out in the middle of nowhere, feel free to build as many condos as you please, because you wouldn't bother anyone else. There is a reason why we have official plans, zoning laws, and public hearings over all this stuff. The OMB, unfortunately, views all this work as something less than a suggestion.

Here's another analogy. Buying a car does not give you the right to drive on whichever side of the road you please. Imagine if you're obeying the traffic rules, but some people decide they just don't have to, and the traffic court agrees with them. That's what the OMB is like.

Comment: The cycle of terror attacks has not become routine. Governments and the media still sensationalize them. Governments do it because it plays nicely into their political machinations. The media does it because it sells. And terrorists commit terror for both those reasons. If governments and media stopped sensationalizing so-called terror attacks, the motive for their use would be greatly diminished.

Try searching for "bus crash deaths" in your favourite news app. Here's what I get:

May 24, Dubai, 7 killed 35 injured.
May 22, Mexico, 17 killed 31 injured.
May 13, Turkey, 23 killed.
May 7, Tanzania, 36 schoolchildren killed...

These tragedies are duly reported but they're not sensationalized. They get a column inch only, because they can't be exploited by politicians or the media. And this is true even though often singly, and especially collectively, bus crashes cause far greater casualties than any terrorist could hope to inflict.

Comment: I still remember several of Boris Spremo's photographs after forty years and more because they were so wonderfully memorable.

The one in this obit of former PM John Diefenbaker working on his memoirs on a beach in Barbados in 1977 is a great example of Spremo's artistry.

Even though this is a side shot of Dief The Chief and all you can see is his silhouette in dark shadow, anyone who knew him or who followed Mr. Diefenbaker's career could instantly identify him by the outline of his unique hairstyle and facial profile.

It takes artistry including imagination to go for and set up a photograph like this one.

RIP, Boris Spremo, you were a true artist with your camera and it is a real pleasure to revisit some of your work including in this obituary.

Comment: The article doesn't give a very good picture of what happened in this case.  It says that at the time she was finally admitted to the hospital a "septic infection had infiltrated her bloodstream".  That's septicemia, probably with septic shock, but severe pain is not a normal feature of septicemia.  The question is, what was the initial locus of infection?  It doesn't really say even where the pain was.  Was it abdominal pain from peritonitis?  Pelvic pain from a reproductive tract infection?  Pain from a urinary tract infection? Or was it extremity pain?  My guess is necrotizing fasciitis, which can be extremely tricky to diagnose in early stages.  In fact the main early sign of necrotizing fasciitis is intense pain out of proportion to outward signs.  Hard to know from what's in the article what happened here, or if the E.R. was negligent, but people shouldn't jump to conclusions either way from the info presented here.

Comment: "At the federal level, Article II of the United States Constitution states in Section 4 that "The President, Vice President, and all civil Officers of the United States shall be removed from Office on Impeachment for, and conviction of, Treason, Bribery, or other High Crimes and Misdemeanors." The House of Representatives has the sole power of impeaching, while the United States Senate has the sole power to try all impeachments. The removal of impeached officials is automatic upon conviction in the Senate. In Nixon v. Comment: Most of the caregiver delivery system in through the private sector.  Nonprofits in particular need to know that government is willing and able to pay some of this cost, and for contracts, to pay on time.  Too often these organizations must wait and wait for overdue payments.  This, in turn, impacts the attractiveness of future employees taking a chance on joining a caregiving organization.  Yes, individual family and friends are carrying the load, but for so many, the availability of a care giver will depend on the health of the private delivery system.  And this means we must also ensure quality control through licensing, the Long Term Care Ombudsman, and other elements of oversight. When we say NO to a funding request from the Department of Health, we are saying no to our seniors.

Comment: Of course, you wouldn't want to send a person to someplace where they might gain reasons to not drink. No, instead, we'll just suck them dry financially, physically, and spiritually by sending them to jail and then to a treatment program that teaches them that life has no meaning beyond this moment and that the only thing in life that matters is staying sober. 

AA and other spiritually-based 12 Step programs are effective. That's why they're court-ordered. Medical and psychological "treatment" programs have huge failure rates -- almost double that of 12 Step programs. Having experience with the treatment programs through working in mental health, I believe its because they don't give the addict anything to replace the drugs with except will-power and cognitive exercises. It promotes hopelessness. 

That said, not every program works for every addict. Diversity of choices is a good thing.

Comment: The notion that buying spin-offs is a value play is false.  Value investing requires an understanding of the underpinnings of the business, including management.  This is patently impossible in this scenario.

Spin-offs are capital market imbalances that can have edge for investors set up to buy them.  They fall in the same category as shorting firms that split their stocks, participating in large block trades to change ownership structures (think Nissan-Renault) and a handful  of others.

A far better approach is to view markets in a 3 dimensional way:
 1.) the Chicago price, that is fair value;
 2.) the supply and demand factors, who are the owners, sellers, buyers, what has changed (the above falls in this category); and 
3.) The price statistics. Looking at where prices trade over time relative to fair value.  If a stock is always cheap, it is a value trap.

Investing is much more complex than you suggest and the real story of value is much more nuanced and inaccessible to retail.

Comment: There was an old rumor that the High School Graduation Qualifying Exam (HSGQE) from the mid-00s was actually only geared to test an 8th-9th grade intelligence, yet was a metric suitable to rule the student qualified to graduate. Many jokes were made of why we were still there then to finish 10-12th.

That said, we need to keep kids in there until 18. Not only because we'd have an idle population of teens without jobs if we didn't keep them in school, but studies at university and college levels have found radically increasing needs for remedial courses (sub-101 level), particularly Math and English to bring high school graduates up to college caliber. Public schools aren't getting our students there.

We should improve courses, and bring back vocational type classes such as shop to give students wider diversity in their education, and also let them find that maybe they want to pursue vocational learning as opposed to college learning.

Comment: The experience with our kids is that split class is a total disaster. Can we really expect from a teacher, no matter how good she is, to be able to give enough attention to a student from one grade while she is spending half of her time with the other grade? can we expect the kids to stay calm while there is a discussion in class that they are not part of?
The split class also creates needless social problems since in most cases the older kids will not accept the younger into the group, and if the younger have only 10 kids in this class were only 5 of them are girls it limits the friendship she can develop, and add to her feeling of being an outsider.
There was a good reason for having the kids in grades by year and we should keep it that way for their benefit. In high school, they do understand the negative impact of the split class idea and they chose not to implement it.
These split classes are meant to serve only the system not the kids and the parents should insist to cancel it.

Comment: Have you ever seen the inside of a slaughterhouse or the longhouses commercial chickens are housed in? I call that suffering.

I lump suffering on the "bad" side of the scale, don't you? Why would I promote suffering? Is a chicken nugget really so tasty that you would condemn a bird to misery and suffering? Do you ever feel guilt?

I'll bet one in a hundred meat eaters know where their food comes from. I suspect if they saw and heard and smelled the inside of those places, they'd throw up.

There are advantages to not eating meat. You know them: better health, less water and air pollution, less water use, less wasted agricultural land and fewer animals that suffer.

Comment: Mike thanks for your willingness to dialogue on the issues.  As to the SCOTUS picks, I would agree that it is unlikely that the courts will ever reverse Roe v. Wade.  However, strict constructionist judges have proven far more willing to allow states to impose restrictions on abortion, such as ultrasounds, which I believe have been key to some of the reduction we appear to be seeing.  However, the stronger argument is internationally.  The Mexico City policy, which was created by President Reagan, prevented US dollars from supporting abortion abroad.  It was reversed by Clinton and Obama, but upheld by both George H. W. and George W. Bush.   Paying for abortion abroad likely has a more immediate impact than anything done domestically.   Thus if Mr. Trump reimposes the Mexico City policy, I would see this as a major win.  But like you, I will need to wait and see, and offer lots of prayer in the meantime.  God bless.

Comment: I think Fr. Reese is right as to the complexity of our tax code.  That complexity is amplified by politicians in BOTH parties who have long used the code to implement their public party, for better or worse.  

I honestly can see both sides of arguments on where to from here.  My hope as the country inches ever closer to what I think is an inevitable rework of the code, is that we can turn the temperature down on that debate.  That kind of heat only gets in the way of needed change.  To do this right, we're gong o have to recognize that businesses and citizens, rich and poor, will all have some legitimate needs from the code, some "wish list" or "great to have" kind of stuff."  And there will be no shortage of greed trying to seep in as well.  To the degree we can find a way to make this into a public dialog, instead of the old "smoke filled room" kind of process, it seems to me there SHOULD be at least a chance of getting this done well...

Comment: It's not necessary to point out that Cal Thomas is himself about as rigid as they get, suffering as he does from ideological rigor mortis.  

But he make this misleading statement: "Many on the left believe school choice should not be available to poor children, not because school choice is a bad idea but because the Democratic Party doesn't want to alienate teachers' unions that oppose it."  

The issue here is the survival of public education as it has existed for over a century.  "School choice," in practice means a free-for-all sort-out according to income and, for the poor, place of residence.  More enabled chldren quickly gravitate to better performing schools, leaving the public schools, who have no choice about the students they will accept (as charter schools do), to take the social and academic problem kids.  Better teachers naturally gravitate to a better class of student, so the public schools also end up with the worst teachers.  In short, dump those who need help most.

Comment: Trump invited the Pope for lunch on his mega yacht, the Pope accepted, and during lunch a puff of wind blew the pontiff’s hat off, right into the water.

It floated off about 50 feet, then the wind died down and it just floated in place.

The crew and the secret service were scrambling to launch a boat to go get it, when Trump waved them off, saying “Never mind, boys, I’ll get it.”

Trump climbed over the side of the yacht, walked on the water to the hat, picked it up, walked back on the water, climbed onto the yacht and handed the pope his hat.

The crew was speechless. The security team and the pope’s entourage were speechless.

No one knew what to say, not even the pope.

But that afternoon, Michael Gerson, NBC, CBS, ABC, MSNBC and CNN all knew how to cover the story. Their banner headlines read, “Trump can’t swim.”

This was the most important staff position for a new political party seeking to define itself in policy terms and Manning at the time did, indeed, think Harper was the smartest man in the room - after himself.  

Manning always thought he was really the smartest man in the room.   But 3 time federal election winner Harper - the only PM in history to win 3 in a row with a larger share of votes and seats each time - proved that he was a far smarter political strategist than Preston was.

Comment: Notwithstanding some of the very valid truths about China in this article, lets not be swept up with hysterical nonsense of naivete.   First consider that Canada is a pipsqueak of a country relative to the United States and China.  Our population is a mere 36 million China's is 1.4 billion.  Moreover we are no more than an appendix economy to the United States.  It would be foolish to believe we have much influence on either country.  Especially a burgeoning superpower that is bound to dominate the world economy for the 100 or so years.

I do believe that Trudeau's approach is more constructive given the constraints of our size and influence.  We should make clear that we don't approve of China's negative behavior, but that doesn't mean that we should be forever lecturing them about it.  There are more subtle ways of gaining influence.

Comment: So even though it's constitutional, legal and, incidentally, fair it shouldn't be done, and you find the tyranny of the minority more acceptable. The minority already has an oversized say because of the Senate and because the smallest number of electoral votes a low population state can have is 3, even if the population doesn't warrant it, but you want them to keep extra power by maintaining the current structure. 
As for constitutionality, the section you quoted says that Congress's consent is required only if the compact infringes on the purview of the federal government. The constitution gives exclusive rights over the EC to state legislatures (Art 2, Sect 1) so the section you quote does not apply. I believe in a fair electoral process and you believe that certain people should hold more power. Obviously you don't care about constitutionality or legality or even the process, just how you want things to be so your side can control the outcome whether it's equitable and fair or not.

Comment: My son was born in 1994 and I face regret every single day for not banking his cord blood.  Had I only known that his condition (to which he has spent well over 12 years of daily therapy and still plagues him through adulthood) could have been reversed via his cord blood, well...  it would have changed both of our lives.  The potential for stem cells in cord blood is limitless.  And the likelihood of a match with other members of the family is very good so your baby's cord blood could be used to save his grandparents!  I have known people with sick kids to have another child in hopes of harvesting matching cord blood for a sick child.  For $1,000 and minimal annual fees?  It's a no brainer, imo. EVERY SINGLE DAY, I REGRET NOT HAVING BANKED MY CHILD'S CORD BLOOD.  I think this is a great gift a grandparent can make as new moms have other things on their mind.

Comment: The challenge for Governor Ige, as I see it, is not that he is an ineffective leader. What I see his problem is that he has a lack of cheerleaders around him, shoring up his leadership message for the state. Many have compared Ige to Ariyoshi, and those comparisons are quite accurate. However, for Ariyoshi, he had a team of voices around him that would also promote the state administrations positions in various ways - from the guiding hand of Inouye to the more enthusiastic ways of Waihee and Cayetano. Comment: One question would be, what does it shift our dependence to?  Because if it's a shift toward wind & solar then it's likely to lead to a boondoggle.  Very few people seem to understand the fundamental problems with diffuse, intermittent energy sources.  In fact it's not even quite correct to call them 'sources,' e.g. PV solar in Germany, with similar insolation as western Washington, was shown recently to be a net energy sink, with an EROI of less than one (consuming more energy than it creates), similar to ethanol.  Let's not enact legislation that sends us down that road again.

At the very least we should be sure that the social cost of carbon isn't actually negative.  The planet is currently greening, at least in part due to higher CO2 levels, and that's likely to be a benefit.  The notion that we should pay now to avoid paying later is based generally on our current understanding of the climate, which is primitive, and specifically on climate models, which are even more primitive.

Comment: Housing costs reflect the standard of living in the community.  In the Eugene area the costs of all goods and services are quite high.......not Portland, not Seattle and not the Bay Area, but still quite high.  For folks working at or near the minimum wage that creates real issues.

The idea of "affordable housing" is a dream and CANNOT BE ACHIEVED without significant public funding to support it.  Section 8 housing is an example.

However, at the price of bare land, with the costs of permits and systems development fees, and with the price of construction,  we will not see privately developed housing at "affordable prices" for lower income families.  It simply doesn't "pencil."  
Only if it made economic sense,  would there be privately developed "affordable housing" available.  So realistically, any plans to increase the availability of such housing must include that significant government spending, and today any additional taxation for any purpose is a very hard sell.

Comment: Here's the challenge for many Canadian companies looking to go global, compared to a US firm: the gap between the size of the domestic market and a global one. We're a small market; Canadian companies can only grow to a limited size on this market. But, the jump to be able to export (in terms of scale and business capacity) is often a big one. U.S. firms, on the other hand, have a market as big as Canada in California alone; by the time they are serving a U.S. market they are much bigger -- and much better prepared to go global. How do we help Canadian firms jump that bigger gap?

Comment: Joe,

Canada could give the US a detailed counter argument for each item on its wish list as well as its own wants but it may not be worth the effort. Such arguments could look like this:

- the US subsidizes its dairy sector and is producing a glut of dairy products that it wants to dump onto our markets at below the cost of production. Dumping is not allowed under WTO rules.

US trade negotiators are not stupid and already know the US is not a fair trader. I am confident they have seen our positions on dairy, dispute resolutions and several other issues. We are better off not letting the US see our cards just yet.

Comment: Cats are the definitive source of the cat parasite Toxoplasma gondii.  PetMD is out of date and flat out wrong about Tg transmission in this country.  The modern (as of 2012) assays can differentiate fecal source oocyst infections from tissue source (meat) infections.  Either way, the cat was the definitive host (original source) of Tg infections in both wildlife and humans.  The only place the parasite completes its sexual reproduction is in the gut of a cat.  When the cat is infected and shedding the Tg oocycsts, as single cat sheds millions of oocysts in its feces, which can wash into the water and ocean.  Cats are NOT just the vector, but in fact the definitive host of the Tg parasite.  A single oocyst can infect a pig, and a human.  A single cat can infect millions of other animals.  Tissue cysts in pork or fecal oocysts on contaminated lettuces all originally came from cats.  No cats, Tg would not continue to spread beyond the lifetime of the other cat infected animals.

Comment: Take your self-righteousness elsewhere.  I didn't say anything to "excuse" DUI offenders.  I made the observation (which I'm qualified by professional experience to make) that inexperienced drinkers often simply don't comprehend how insidious the effects of alcohol are--they think they're unimpaired when they're not.  

It's not illegal to drive after simply imbibing alcohol.  What's illegal is to drive "intoxicated."  The Alaska Supreme Court has held that "intoxicated" means "impaired"--which isn't very explanatory.  As a practical matter, it means above o.o8% BA.  Nobody alive can tell just by how much he's drunk or how he feels at the moment whether he's above or below that limit.  But more experienced drinkers can usually assess the risks--of both their driving ability and their blowing 0.08 or higher--better than 18-year-olds who've only just acquired the legal right to purchase and consume alcohol.

Comment: The RCMP are applying the law as passed by Parliament.

There is a very good legal reason why refugee claimants (not asylum seekers which are a completely different class of persons) are not being charged in respect of their entry to Canada.

Under Article 31 of the 1951 Convention on Refugees Canada has undertaken to not prosecute refugee claimants for illegal entry into Canada including any issues of false documents or fraud relating to that entry.

Canada has enacted that exemption into our domestic law as required by the Convention in various iterations of our immigration legislation over the years. Currently that exemption is contained at s. 133 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.

So no charges because the law exempts refugees recognizing that refugees who are fleeing persecution are different from other migrants.

Comment: I think there is a useful distinction between "leaving the Church" and "quitting going to church." 

Fifty years ago a lot of people went to church because everybody else did. One's friends and neighbors were there, also clients, prospective-clients, customers, prospective-customers, the boss, the boss's boss, the department chairman and tenure committee, voters (if one were thinking of running for office) party functionaries (who controlled  Christmas turkeys and nominations) the cop who wrote parking tickets and the judge who adjusted the fines on them. People went to church to "network."

If the church is only a place to worship a rather antiquated god by participating in a rather antiquated ritual, not many people go. Young people aren't leaving the Church; they're just quitting going, just like their parents did.

"Hey, why did everybody leave my temple?" thunders Zeus. "We need a survey to find out!"

Comment: United Way isn't the only organization cutting funds for seniors. As a Federal Way Senior Citizen Center board member, we have heard from other organizations saying they will be focusing more on homeless and youth programs, shifting all or most their potential funds away from senior citizens. While I understand the need is deep and well deserved in those other areas, this country has more Americans age 65 and older than at any other time in US history - 40.3 million people. Many who live on fixed incomes while having to pay for rising taxes and healthcare costs. Several of the seniors who come to our center for food and meals, have told me they wouldn't be able get by if it wasn't for what we provide. Many who may become homeless if they don't receive assistance. And it's only going to get exponential worse as the baby boomers are entering this demographic, leaving organizations like ours struggling toserve the needs of our seniors. When will senior citizens' needs become a priority.

Comment: It would appear that the NDP would like the Liberals to repeat what PM Pearson did.

PM Lester Pearson spoke at Temple University in Philadelphia on 2 April 1965, while visiting the United States and voiced his support for a pause in the American bombing of North Vietnam, so that a diplomatic solution to the crisis may unfold. To the Johnson administration, this criticism of American foreign policy on US soil was an intolerable sin. 

Before Pearson had finished his speech, he was summoned to Camp David to meet with Johnson the next day. Johnson, who was notorious for his personal touch in politics, reportedly grabbed Pearson by the lapels and shouted, "Don't you come into my living room and xxx on my rug." Pearson later recounted that the meeting was acrimonious, but insisted the two parted cordially.


I think that Trudeau handled things better that Pearson did.

Comment: First, I just have to say I find the criteria by which of some of my comments are accepted or rejected by the Globe to be incomprehensible. I am trying to find a pattern or some sort of "border" that cannot be transgressed, but, so far, have been unsuccessful. It seems extremely arbitrary, and reminds me of what they used to say of the Court of Equity, i.e. that justice in that Court "was as long as the Chancellor's foot". I would love to have an uninterested third party review the rejected ones and point out just how they are "uncivil".  I have written to the Globe but have not had the courtesy of a response. Alas, there seems no further appeal.
Anyway,  my point was that, understanding decisions in the context of the times they were made, rather than applying the morals of the present, just seems like common sense--unless you expect our ancestors, unlike us, to have been prescient.
Although no different, I await the Chancellor's decision whether this comment is also "uncivil".

Comment: This isn't about possession, it's about use. Many things are allowed to be possessed, and not allowed to be used while driving. An officer can not successfully obtain a search warrant based solely of his sight, or knowledge of, a product which is legal to be possessed, but not legal to be used while driving; Hence, he can't rely on the knowledge of a canine, who possesses the same set of facts, but who can't subjectively differentiate the situation in any more detail than the officer. The burden should be greater for the testimony of a dog, as told by an officer (it's hearsay, at this point anyways, as you alluded to, a dog has never made a great witness, as they don't hold up well under cross-examination) As soon as a dog can 'speak' differently to his handler based on the substance that he detects, the sooner this ruling can be reevaluate. Good job by the COA to limit the power of the government - and of its canine agents:)

Comment: And you failed to read "by virtue of natural law". As you can see our immigration laws was based on jus sanguinis and not jus soli.

Comment: That's just the way it is. Indeed, delivery of those agents is the wild card associated with those weapons. The notion that a wayward rocket hit a dump where inert sarin was stored, magically mixed it somehow without incinerating it and then dispersed the agent over a wide area is ridiculous. Comment: My two sisters and mother live in Miami. One had her whole house destroyed during Andrew, so they wasted no time going online and working the phones last Tuesday morning at 9 am. By noon they had made evacuation decisions, booked tickets and hotels and were gone Wednesday evening and Thursday morning. Yes, they had the money to get out. But a large number of friends, neighbours and relatives, all affluent and educated, with many being really wealthy, still had no idea what to do on Friday, so they all ended up staying in their homes. Worse, they didn't even get together with their families, and many left  80-year old mothers and grandmothers alone in their homes. We're also now discovering many don't have flood insurance, which is astounding. I now realize my immediate family is very different from most of our friends, relatives and acquaintances. It's disturbing, and yes, it's changed how I now look at a lot of people I know.

Comment: Most people who are able to hear have no idea how to speak to those with a hearing impairment.  The abled start to shout.  They get irritated.  They will not repeat themselves.  They talk faster and faster and louder and louder and more and more.   They even get abusive, "Why won't you pay attention?"  Instead, they should speak in a normal tone of voice, at a normal speed, and put their thoughts into short phrases.  This from a study described on NPR years ago.  I'll add that each new idea should be linked in context to what is already being discussed so words can be guessed at.  I find this is the best way to converse with elders.  Other commenters here say, 'speak slowly,' but that is not correct.  Speaking slowly disrupts the familiar patterns of words and makes patterns unrecognizable.  Instead use familiar short phrases.  'How are you today?'  'Nice weather.'  'Did you have snow?'  'Are you warm enough?' All in context sequentially.  All in short phrases.  At normal speed.

Comment: "Available" and required by law:  

In October 2005, Congress passed and President Bush signed into law legislation making it unlawful for any licensed importer, manufacturer or dealer to sell or transfer any handgun unless the transferee is provided with a secure gun storage or safety device. A “secure gun storage or safety device” is defined in 18 U.S.C. § 921(a)(34) as: (A) a device that, when installed on a firearm, is designed to prevent the firearm from being operated without first deactivating the device; (B) a device incorporated into the design of the firearm that is designed to prevent the operation of the firearm by anyone not having access to the device; or C) a safe, gun safe, gun case, lock box, or other device that is designed to be or can be used to store a firearm and that is designed to be unlocked only by means of a key, a combination, or other similar means. Comment: That is a little erronious but understandable. Phone providers are required by law to have 911 service and connect to the regional 911 center. Anchorage has 2 dispatch centers (APD/AFD) and APD always answers first. UAA has a center that gets all 911 calls for landlines at the campus, but not cell calls. ASD does not have a 911 center itself.
The state does not operate a single state-wide center either. In Mat-Su AST is dispatched by Wasilla Police which has a center, and Palmer Police have their own with Fire/EMS for the Borough. Fairbanks has a city center, a University center, and an AST center. Kenai has a joint center.

These come from various funding sources, and it's also important to remember that building a consolidated center is very expensive, on the order of millions of dollars. Mat-Su has looked at this for years, but there simply is no money (and no agreement) on how to make it a reality.

Comment: The issue of affordability is an unfortunate side-effect of a much larger problem in Hawaii. Affordability is an  equation not a number. Income + Price = "Affordability". What Hawaii needs are new jobs and new industries. We need to open our doors legislatively to Tech and other industries that are not cyclical like construction or tourism, aren't straining on our natural resources like Ag, and aren't land-locked. We need to open up our state to the world, embrace technology and offer real, competitive incentives for people to come here versus California or Seattle. In a global environment where changes and advances are immediate and ever constant, it's imperative that we keep up. We will never have the natural resources, the funds, nor the infrastructure to continue pushing construction, tourism and Ag as the main drivers of what will soon be our children's economy.

Comment: It’s no surprise that the opioid epidemic has filled Big Pharma’s pockets but the cost to society has been tremendous. According to the article, 1 in 10 people have access to treatment, but is it the right treatment? Most treatment options are traditional rehabs or prescriptions for opioid replacement drugs such as Suboxone. If we keep using our resources to repeat the same failed drug rehab programs, the epidemic will continue to worsen and more lives will be lost. We must learn from failed treatment methods and offer individualized medical detox and counseling to support the whole person.

Comment: Mr. Trudeau is different from the previous PM in the sense that he is mostly hands-off and smiles more.  In substance, he is really not that much different from any other PM in recent memory regardless of political stripe in that there is the usual sense of entitlement, partisanship and ego that drives anyone with an appetite for public office.  Like any other campaigning party leader, he can make a list of promises as long as your arm and then blame the previous government when those promises are broken.  Now, he is at the point where he must be tired of the stylistic performances and realizes he must do more than portray an image or echo the same old mantras. Comment: The article mentioned that the inquiry has gone over well -covered ground. What else could there be ? There have already been over reports on the same issue, there really wasn't any possibility that new evidence would be revealed , or different findings. It was also unlikely that someone would come up with a new plan to locate those that are missing. It was never clear what the goals were ,other then the fact that the word answers was used by politicians and other stakeholders. It would be virtually impossible after this length of time that answers would be found, yet many of the participants had perhaps been unfairly led to believe that they would get answers. If anything the one answer that has emerged, is that this was not he way to conduct an inquiry.

Comment: The issue of sequestration amounts and time are not explored in enough depth and may appear to be better solutions to a long term problem than they are.  Soil may retain 20% of the carbon but will become saturated in 20-30 years.  Trees have longer term sequestration and may retain that carbon for decades to centuries. The carbon that is being added by burning fossil fuels was sequestered in the order of thousands to millions of years. The use of shorter term sequestration may delay the problems but longer term sequestration must be found.

Comment: That's the whole point! The article is cherry picked info and talking points. 

It would be easier to take an article titled "... causes of climate change" if the first half wasn't about the effects of climate change. Effects are irrelevant to the causes (that's the sky is falling part).  It's a common aspect of propaganda that the stated point (in this case, anthropogenic climate change) is different that the points made in the article (effects of climate change).

The only place causes are mentioned is volcanic emissions. They produce little CO2 but much SO2, and others.  How does SO2 and others fare as a greenhouse gases?  That gets complicated. But it doesn't matter. We have not substitute for coal/oil. Until we invent some radically new energy source, we burn fuels we have. 

A serious question: what would you suggest? On an individual level we could use less, letting other people use more.  On a national level we could use less, letting other nations use more.  Any benefit there?
